titlestmt.title: Eighteen Heads of Poets : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi , University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries April 2024
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of Blake’s Eighteen Heads of Poets. These tempera paintings, produced by Blake between c. 1800 and 1803, were commissioned by William Hayley as decorations for his upper library at Turret House, his residence in Felpham, Sussex. In addition, we are publishing an exhibition curated by Mark Crosby that reconstructs Turret House and the upper library to show how Blake’s paintings were sequenced and hung.
Blake had at least begun preliminary work on the Heads of Poets by the fall of 1800, as indicated by his letter to Hayley of 26 November: "Absorbed by the poets Milton, Homer, Camoens, Ercilla, Ariosto, and Spenser, whose physiognomies have been my delightful study…" (Erdman page 714). The sizes of the canvas panels, approximately 40.5 cm. high and of varying widths, were determined by their intended setting as a frieze between the bookcases and ceiling. The choice of authors to portray rested with Hayley.
In most of the eighteen paintings in the group, Blake included, right and left of the central portrait, either characters or events presented in the writer's works or emblematic motifs that allude to those works. The introductory essay and the Editors’ Notes to each painting indicate the probable sources for the portraits and the literary and pictorial references of the side motifs.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

provenance.name: Manchester Art Gallery
provenance.note: The group of eighteen paintings commissioned from Blake by William Hayley c. 1800; his cousin, Captain Godfrey, by inheritance in 1820; the group sold c. 1840 and dispersed (C. J. Toovey had at least five of the paintings); the group reunited by William Russell no later than 1863; sold from Russell's collection, Christie's, 5 Dec. 1884, in individual lots as follows: lot 126, Object 1, Homer (£8.8s.); lot 124, Object 2, Demosthenes, misidentified as "Euripides" (£9.9s.); lot 125, Object 3, Cicero, misidentified as "Lucan" (£6.16s.6d.); lot 123, Object 4, Dante (£8.8s); lot 111, Object 5, Chaucer (£5.5s.); lot 121, Object 6, Camoens (£7.17s.6d.); lot 119, Object 7, Ercilla, misidentified as "Sidney" (£7.7s.); lot 122, Object 8, Tasso (£8.8s.); lot 112, Object 9, Spenser (£5.5s.); lot 109, Object 10, Shakespeare (£13.2s.6d.); lot 110, Object 11, Milton (£3.13s.6d.); lot 113, Object 12, Dryden (£4.14s.6d.); lot 114, Object 13, Otway (£6.6s.); lot 115, Object 14, Pope (£3.3s.); lot 120, Object 15, Voltaire (£8.8s.); lot 117, Object 16, Klopstock, misidentified as "Blair" (£5.5s.); lot 116, Object 17, Cowper (£6.6s.); lot 118, Object 18, Thomas Alphonso Hayley (£6.16s.6d.). All lots in the 1884 auction purchased by the London art dealer Thomas Agnew & Sons, possibly acting for the Manchester City Art Gallery (now Manchester Art Gallery); accessioned by the Manchester Art Gallery in 1885.

objnote.p: This traditional depiction of the blind Greek poet (c. 950 B.C.) is probably based on Carlo Gregori's 1741 engraving of the Farnese bust of Homer after Giovanni Domenico Campiglia. Blake may have also been influenced by the unsigned engraving of the Farnese bust published in Alexander Pope's translation of the *Iliad* (1720), a work Hayley owned, and by the small portrait on the title page of John Flaxman's outline illustrations to the *Iliad*, first published in 1793. The mouse (left) and frog (right) allude to the *Batrachomyomachia*, a comedic battle between those creatures then attributed to Homer. Their gestures suggest that these are the leaders of the two armies, the mouse Psikharpaks and the frog Physignathus. Both Blake and Hayley are included in the list of subscribers to *The Iliad and Odyssey of Homer* translated by William Cowper (1791), a work that contains in its second volume a translation of the *Batrachomyomachia*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, Homer (c. 950 B.C.), is encircled by a vegetative wreath of intertwining leaves, regularly interspersed with green, and likely new, berries. The wreath is likely composed of the leaves and berries of a fruiting bay. This wreath originates just right of center in the lower margin, and forms a tightly bound circular shape which surrounds Homer's head and neck entirely. Situated inside the wreath, Homer is depicted in the foreground of a bronze-colored disc facing left. He is pictured with short, curly hair which protrudes from a band or tight-fitting cap which encircles Homer's head above his temples. His bearded face is depicted in the style of Greek statuary so that the details of his eyes are not pictured. His eyes appear under their lids as smooth spheres, possibly in recognition of Homer's status as the blind poet. Fabric, likely a robe or some other clothing, is visible on either side of the figure's neck, obscuring the figure's shoulders. A band of cloth, probably also part of the figure's clothing, is visible just under the base of the figure's neck. Several bay leaves extend to the right and left of the wreath in the lower margin of the design. Pictured in the lower margin to the left of the wreath is a mouse, probably Psikharpaks, the mouse prince or "Crumb-thief," a character from Batrachomyomachia, or The Battle of the Frogs and Mice, an epic parody attributed to Homer. Psikharpaks is depicted with his head raised and pointing to the left. His mouth is open so that teeth are visible. He may be speaking or crying out. His snout, nose, and whiskers are all visible, as is his left eye. His left ear is fully visible as is the edge of his right ear, behind his head. Psikharpaks stands erect in an anthropomorphic stance on his hind legs with hind legs spread and hind paws balanced on one of the bay leaves in the attitude of a ferryman. His tail extends in a waving attitude behind his back. Psikharpaks faces left with left foreleg and forepaw raised and paw and claws spread. Psikharpaks's right foreleg is obscured by his body, but his right forepaw holds a long staff or an oar with a long handle which extends up beyond the figure's head. The oar's paddle appears to sink into the lower margin of the image, suggesting that the leaf floats in water. The leaf extends from the central wreath, and appears to be used as a ferry or raft. Pictured in the lower margin to the right of the wreath is a frog, probably Physignathus or the Frog King. Physignathus is depicted facing right with his head raised, pointing up and to the right. His mouth is open and he may be speaking or crying out. His right eye is visible. Physignathus crouches in an anthropomorphic stance on his hind legs with his hind legs bent and webbed hind feet balanced on one of the bay leaves. Physignathus faces right with right foreleg raised and extending out and to the right at 90 degrees. His right forefoot is spread with webbed toes visible and extending or reaching out to the right. Physignathus's left foreleg reaches up above his head and his left forefoot grasps a tall reed. Two tall objects, possibly the trunks of palm trees or Grecian columns, are depicted in both the left and right margins of the design. In the upper corners of the design, vegetation, likely palm fronds, are depicted so that the ends of the leaves or fronds point towards the central image of Homer in the wreath. In the upper right margin, a lyre or harp is partially visible so that part of the instrument's frame and strings are depicted. At least one object is partially visible in the middle of the left margin of this design. The object in the foreground in the left margin is probably a horn of some kind. It has a curved shape and the base, which is pictured, indicates that the horn is probably hollow. The curving shape which arches around this hollow piece is likely the rest of the horn, but the full curl is not visible on the design. In the background, just behind the horn, three tall, thin objects extend towards the upper margin of the design. These may be musical instruments like pipes or reeds, or they may be the pipes of a tsampouna, a bagpipe commonly used in the Greek islands.

objnote.p: The portrait of the Greek orator Demosthenes (c. 383-322 B.C.) is based on an engraving signed by "D. Beyet" and dated 1789, in turn based on a full-length statue in the Vatican. The motifs both right and left are taken from a drawing by William Hayley's son, Thomas Alphonso Hayley (see Object 18 for his portrait). This design was engraved by Blake for Hayley's *An Essay on Sculpture* (1800), titled "The Death of Demosthenes." The kneeling figure far left may be Archias, who discovered Demosthenes committing suicide. The building on the left may be the Temple of Poseidon where the suicide took place. Both portions of the side designs are painted to resemble sculpture, an art for which Thomas Alphonso was apprenticed to John Flaxman.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, Demosthenes (c. 383-322 B.C.), is encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. The wreath is likely composed of oak leaves. This wreath originates in the center of the design's lower margin where the stems of the oak leaves are visibly intertwined. One of the intertwining stems may be a ribbon, cord, or rope which helps the wreath form a circular shape surrounding Demosthenes's head and neck entirely. Situated inside the wreath, Demosthenes is pictured with short, curly hair and is facing left. His right ear is visible. His bearded face is depicted in the style of Greek statuary so that the details of his hair and eyes are not pictured in great detail. His eyes appear under their lids as smooth spheres. Two figures are pictured to the left of the wreath in the left margin of the design, though some of the details of these figures are very lightly rendered making some of their features barely visible. One reclining nude male figure faces right. The figure may be Demosthenes in the act of committing suicide. The figure gestures or appeals with his left arm which is raised at 45 degrees. His left hand is outstretched with palm facing up and his thumb and two fingers are visible. The figure's bearded face is pictured in profile with his head tilting up and to the right. His right ear is visible, as is his short, curly hair. Other details of his face are more difficult to see. The figure rests on his right arm which is bent at the elbow with the forearm supporting the figure's reclining torso, shoulders, and head. An indeterminate object appears to be held in the figure's right fist--possibly the reed filled with poison that Demosthenes used to kill himself. The figure is mostly nude except for a single draped piece of cloth, clothing, or drapery of some kind that hangs over the figure's left shoulder and partially obscures the figure's upper body. His chest is mostly bare, as are his genitals and legs. His legs are extended and point to the right. His left leg is slightly bent at the knee so that his left thigh and knee are visible, but his left foot is obscured by his extended right leg. His right leg is fully extended so that his thigh, knee, shin and right foot are all visible. Another figure, probably male, kneels behind the reclining nude male. This may be Archias, who discovered Demosthenes in the act of suicide. This figure, which is probably male, kneels on his right knee with his left arm, leg, and knee obscured by the reclining figure. The kneeling figure is clothed in a short, long-sleeved robe so that his right lower thigh, knee, and upper calf are visible. The figure's upper body tilts forward so that he may be supporting the reclining figure. His face is depicted in profile, and he faces down and right. His shoulders and upper body are angled forward and down over the recline figure. His clothed right arm is visible, but his hand is obscured by the reclining figure. In the background behind both figures is a building or structure with a smooth wall visible behind both figures. This may be the Temple of Poseidon where Demosthenes committed suicide. The structure appears to have a gable roof with one long ridge typical of ancient Greek temples. The figures may be resting on a platform, plinth, or step associated with the temple. This platform structure is obscured by the central wreath, but is visible on both sides of the wreath. Three male figures are pictured to the right of the design's central wreath, partially obscured by the platform or step. Their rendering is light, so that some of their features are indistinct. These figures may be Macedonian sentries or soldiers sent to discover the fleeing Demosthenes. The figures are depicted either climbing the plinth or step on which the dying Demosthenes is pictured, or partially obscured by it so that each figure's lower legs beneath their knees are not visible. Each figure is wearing protective clothing or holds weapons or protective gear. All three are wearing helmets. The figure to the far right of the design is pictured in profile facing left. His upper body and arms are obscured by a large round, or oval-shaped shield. His left upper thigh and buttock are visible, so that the figure appears to be nude from the waist down or wearing tights. The figure's right inner thigh is also visible, but, like the other figures, his lower legs are obscured by a plinth or platform that he is standing on or climbing. This figure also holds a spear or staff which is positioned between the figure's face in profile and the shield he carries. To the right of this figure stands another soldier. This figure faces left and wears a plumed helmet with a chinstrap and a cloak or robe which obscures his body. He also is depicted carrying or holding a spear or staff. Directly to the right of the central wreath is another male figure pictured facing forward and also wearing a plumed helmet with a chinstrap and protective clothing (possibly a leather breastplate or light armor). His right arm is outstretched at 135 degrees, but is obscured by the central wreath below the elbow. He may be wearing a cloak or some other type of draped fabric over his left shoulder, but the details of the image are unclear. This figure is depicted in the most active attitude of all three, with his right leg extended as though he may be climbing the plinth.

His shoulders and upper body are angled forward and down over the recline figure. His clothed right arm is visible, but his hand is obscured by the reclining figure.

In the background behind both figures is a building or structure with a smooth wall visible behind both figures. This may be the Temple of Poseidon where Demosthenes committed suicide. The structure appears to have a gable roof with one long ridge typical of ancient Greek temples. The figures may be resting on a platform, plinth, or step associated with the temple. objnote.p: The portrait of Marcus Tullius Cicero (106-43 B.C.) is based on an engraving after a drawing by Peter Paul Rubens of a bust of the Roman orator. One such engraving by M. Burg is the frontispiece in *Aeschines et Demosthenes de Corona*, ed. Petrus Foulkes and Johan Friend (1715), a copy of which was in Hayley’s library. The designs right and left picture the death of Cicero at the hands of Roman soldiers. His death is described in many publications, including at least one book in Hayley’s library, Conyers Middleton’s *The History of the Life of M. Tullius Cicero* (1741).

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, Marcus Tullius Cicero (106-43 B.C.), is encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. The wreath is likely composed of oak leaves, acorns, and grain tassels. This wreath likely originates in the center of the design's lower margin where the stems of the oak leaves are visibly intertwined. The wreath forms a circular shape surrounding Marcus Tullius Cicero's head and neck entirely. Situated inside the wreath, Marcus Tullius Cicero is pictured in great detail, with short hair and is facing left. Cicero's right ear is visible. On either side of his neck, clothing, possibly the traditional robe of a Roman statesman, is visible. One prominent figure and a group of figures are pictured to the left of the wreath in the left margin of the design, though some of the details of these figures are very lightly rendered making some of their features barely visible. One standing, bearded male figure faces left with his left arm outstretched and left hand pointing towards the design's central figure (Cicero's wreathed head). This figure may be the centurion, or a Roman soldier following Mark Antony's orders to find and capture Cicero, who was declared an enemy of the state following Caesar's death. This figure is wears a striking red cloak, plumed helmet, armor, knee-length tunic or skirt, and sandals in the typical costume of a Roman soldier. The figure's right arm hangs by his side, and he may be holding a sword in his right hand, though the details of this aspect of the figure are unclear--the sword may belong to one of the soldiers behind him instead. The figure's right leg is bent at the knee with his right foot clearly lifted in the air, so that his left leg and foot support his body. The figure may be in the act of moving or walking towards the center of the design. A group of at least four (possibly more) Roman soldiers stand just behind and to the left of the centurion. The details of three of these figures are very difficult to distinguish, though it seems clear that all have similar characteristics. These menacing figures all face left and all wear armor, helmets, and sandals with legs bare below the knee. The foremost soldier in this group of figures is pictured with his right arm bent at the elbow, and grasping a spear or staff in his right hand, the base of which rests on the ground. The figure directly behind and to the right of this soldier figure may carry a shield, though the details are not clear. The point of at least one more spear or staff is visible over the heads of this group of soldiers. Behind this group of soldiers, light washes of blue and orange coloring suggest a landscape or a seascape which is barely visible. Under the centurion's outstretched right arm and pointing hand, the trunks and branches of at least two trees are visible, probably meant to indicate the forest through which Cicero attempted to flee Mark Antony's men toward the port of Gaeta. At the top of the left margin some vegetation is pictured in the foreground of the design. These may be palm fronds or another type of indeterminate vegetation. To the right of the central wreath, a Roman soldier with the red cloak and red plumed helmet stands facing away. His right arm is raised above his head, with a sword grasped in his right fist. This soldier is in the act of beheading another figure. His left arm is bent at the elbow so that his left hand holds a scabbard behind his back. He is also wearing the armor and sandals of a Roman soldier, and may be the same figure, the centurion, pictured in the left margin of the design. Directly behind this figure is another figure who may be Cicero in the act of being executed by beheading. This figure is depicted bending or leaning forward and facing right, with his bare head and neck prominently visible, and situated leaning over the long arm of a structure or vehicle of some sort (probably the litter, or Lectica, from which he is said to have leaned out of as a surrender to his execution). The lectica is depicted with long arms for Cicero's slaves to support the structure both in front and behind the conveyance. The Lectica is pictured with a platform and seat for a rider to rest in, and a curtained cover or roof with cloth drapery is also visible in this image. To the left of the executioner, a figure in a tunic is pictured standing between the arms of the lectica. This figure faces left, with his head bent and face covered. He is likely male, and appears to be wearing a short tunic and sandals. He is likely one of Cicero's slaves, hiding his face as Cicero is executed. In the top right of the design, some indeterminate vegetation is visible just below the right corner of the design. In the central space, and at the top right of the design is pictured a nude male figure who appears to preside over the execution of Cicero. This is likely Hermes, as the figure is represented holding a long staff around which two snakes are intertwined. Hermes holds this staff with his left arm and hand. The details of this figure are difficult to distinguish, but he may be pictured with a winged helmet, and winged sandals.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, Marcus Tullius Cicero, is encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. Situated inside the wreath, Marcus Tullius Cicero is pictured in great detail, with short hair and is facing left. His right ear is visible. On either side of his neck, clothing, possibly the traditional robe of a Roman statesman, is visible.

The head and neck of a male figure, Marcus Tullius Cicero, is encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. The wreath is likely composed of oak leaves, acorns, and grain tassels. This wreath likely originates in the center of the design's lower margin where the stems of the oak leaves are visibly intertwined. The wreath forms a circular shape surrounding Marcus Tullius Cicero's head and neck entirely.

One prominent figure and a group of figures are pictured to the left of the wreath in the left margin of the design, though some of the details of these figures are very lightly rendered making some of their features barely visible. One standing, bearded male figure faces left with his left arm outstretched and left hand pointing towards the design's central figure (Cicero's wreathed head). This figure may be the centurion, or a Roman soldier following Mark Antony's orders to find and capture Cicero, who was declared an enemy of the state following Caesar's death. The figure may be in the act of moving or walking towards the center of the design.

The figure directly behind and to the right of this soldier figure may carry a shield, though the details are not clear. Behind this group of soldiers, light washes of blue and orange coloring suggest a landscape or a seascape which is barely visible.

Under the centurion's outstretched right arm and pointing hand, the trunks and branches of at least two trees are visible, probably meant to indicate the forest through which Cicero attempted to flee Mark Antony's men toward the port of Gaeta.

At the top of the left margin some vegetation is pictured in the foreground of the design. These may be palm fronds or another type of indeterminate vegetation. In the top right of the design, some indeterminate vegetation is visible.

This soldier is in the act of beheading another figure. His left arm is bent at the elbow so that his left hand holds a scabbard behind his back. He is also wearing the armor and sandals of a Roman soldier, and may be the same figure, the centurion, pictured in the left margin of the design.

Directly behind the centurion figure is another figure who may be Cicero in the act of being executed by beheading. This figure is depicted bending or leaning forward and facing right, with his bare head and neck prominently visible, and situated leaning over the long arm of a structure or vehicle of some sort (probably the litter, or Lectica, from which he is said to have leaned out of as a surrender to his execution).

This figure is depicted bending or leaning forward and facing right, with his bare head and neck prominently visible, and situated leaning over the long arm of a structure or vehicle of some sort (probably the litter, or Lectica, from which he is said to have leaned out of as a surrender to his execution). The lectica is depicted with long arms for Cicero's slaves to support the structure both in front and behind the conveyance. To the left of the executioner, a figure in a tunic is pictured standing between the arms of the lectica. This figure faces left, with his head bent and face covered. He is likely male, and appears to be wearing a short tunic and sandals. He is likely one of Cicero's slaves, hiding his face as Cicero is executed.

In the central space, and at the top right of the design is pictured a nude male figure who appears to preside over the execution of Cicero. This is likely Hermes, as the figure is represented holding a long staff around which two snakes are intertwined. Hermes holds this staff with his left arm and hand. The details of this figure are difficult to distinguish, but he may be pictured with a winged helmet, and winged sandals.

objnote.p: The portrait of the Italian poet Dante Alighieri (1265-1321) is taken from his portrayal in Raphael’s *Disputation of the Holy Sacrament*, probably known to Blake through one of many engravings of the fresco in the Vatican. The chain (left) and the seated man with four children (right) picture the story of Ugolino in Dante’s “Inferno” in his *Divine Comedy*. Blake illustrated the Ugolino narrative several times, first in a pencil sketch datable to c. 1780-85 (Butlin 207 recto), later in *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* plate 16, in his Dante illustrations of 1824-27 (Butlin 812.68), and a tempera painting of c. 1826 (Butlin 805). None of these versions is compositionally similar to the design accompanying this head of Dante. Blake may have acquired his copy of Henry Boyd’s translation of *The Inferno* (1785) from Hayley as early as 1800 (see Bentley page 686, no. 721).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The head and neck of a male figure, Dante Alighieri (1265-1321), encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves and fruit is pictured centrally in this design. The wreath is likely composed of bay leaves and bay berries. This wreath likely originates in the center of the design's lower margin where the stems of two bay branches are visibly overlapping. The wreath forms a circular shape surrounding Dante's head, neck, and right shoulder entirely. Situated inside the wreath, Dante is pictured in great detail, with short, curling hair visible peeking from a cloth head covering, or a hood, and he is facing left, looking over his right shoulder. In addition to a cloth head covering, the figure is pictured with a vegetative wreath or crown, likely composed of laurel leaves, which rests on top of his headdress, crossing his forehead and the crown of his head. This crown arches in the same direction as the wreath of bay leaves, so that it appears to add foliage to the wreath. His right shoulder is visible and is clothed in drapery, a cloak, or a robe of some kind. At the top margin of the design, some clusters of diagonal lines in both upper corners of the design might represent indeterminate vegetation, or an indeterminate or abstract design of some kind. In the left margin of the design, an abstract design of indeterminate foliage is visible to the far left of the central wreath and across the upper left margin of the design. The rectangular shapes of four large stones or bricks are also visible in the lower left margin of the design, suggesting the presence of a stone wall or stone steps. A chain appears to be fastened to one of these stones or bricks. One large circular link is attached to the stone, with several links of the metal chain curving down and towards the central wreath, eventually disappearing behind the central wreath's foliage. This chain and the stone wall suggest the interior of a prison, which is further evidenced by the scene in the right margin of the design. In it, an adult male figure (Ugolino, a character in Dante's "Inferno" in his Divine Comedy) is pictured seated and facing left with his face in profile. The scene is pictured against a stone wall and under a stone archway or doorway, and the chain pictured in the left margin of the design reappears and is visibly fastened to the figure's left wrist, and extends down his left side. Ugolino is depicted wearing a robe or gown of some kind, with short curly hair and a curly beard which falls at least to his chest. His wrists are manacled, and his hands are crossed in his lap with his right hand covering his left. His robe obscures his legs, however they may be crossed, and what appear to be his bare feet are visible at the hem of his robe. A child is seated on his lap (one of his sons), and the child's right arm wraps around his father's torso. The boy faces out, but looks up towards his father's face. The boy has short, curly hair and his shoulders and chest are visible, clothed in some sort of tunic or drapery, however, his lower body is obscured by his father's body. Another child, another of Ugolino's sons, appears to be standing behind his father's legs, and rests his head against the back of Ugolino's open right hand. This child's right shoulder and face are visible, but the rest of his body is obscured by his father's legs. He, too, looks upwards towards his father's face, though his physical appearance is not rendered in great detail. Two more figures are pictured in the foreground of this scene, at Ugolino's feet. One figure is seated in the far right corner of the design, with the other figure stretched out in front of the seated figure. This seated figure is of indeterminate gender. They may be a young woman, or a young man in a long robe. This figure has short, curly hair, and faces left, with their face and eyes looking down at the figure stretched out across their lap and on the ground in front of them. The seated figure leans slightly forward, and supports the outstretched figure's head and shoulders as they rest in their lap. The seated figure's legs are obscured by the long robe that they wear, and their arms are partially obscured by the figure resting on them. The outstretched figure appears to be another child, likely one of Ugolino's dying or dead sons. The child's upper body and torso lean against the seated figure behind him while his legs stretch out towards the design's central wreath. The child's head is bent back and resting limply on the seated figure's left forearm, and his eyes and mouth appear to be open. He is pictured in profile, with his left arm hanging limply by his side, and left leg is visible extended. Both his feet are visible, and appear to be bare. The child may be clothed in tight-fitting tights or clothes, or may be nude. At Ugolino's feet, a small round object may be a weight or link attached to the figure's chain, or may be an indeterminate object. Abstract, swirling designs in the right margin of the design may be palm fronds or abstract designs.(

objnote.p: The portrait of the English poet Geoffrey Chaucer (c. 1340s-1400) is probably based on an engraving by George Vertue published in John Urry’s 1721 edition of the *Works of Geoffrey Chaucer*. A copy of the book was in Hayley’s library. One detail, however, suggests that Blake may have consulted other Chaucer portraits engraved by Vertue, one dated 1730 and included in his series of “Twelve Celebrated English Poets” and another published in 1737 and 1740 editions of *The Canterbury Tales*. These two, like Blake’s version, show three buttons on Chaucer’s gown rather than the two buttons in the plate published with Urry’s text. Blake pictures the Merchant left of the central portrait and the Wife of Bath on the right, both from *The Canterbury Tales*. These are closely based on engraved headpieces, unsigned but attributable to Vertue, on pages 66 and 76 in Urry’s edition of Chaucer’s *Works*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the bust of a male figure, Geoffrey Chaucer, is encircled by a vegetative wreath of intertwined stems and flame-like leaves, probably a fruiting laurel wreath. The laurel originates in the center of the lower margin and forms a circular shape which surrounds the bust entirely. Two indistinct, decorative objects, which may be palm fronds or feathers, extend upward from the middle of the left and right margins to the top corners. Situated inside the wreath, Chaucer faces left and looks downward, perhaps toward the small figure to his left. His mouth is closed but he may be smiling. He has a bare forehead, with some hair visible above his right ear, thin eyebrows, and well-defined eye lashes. His tunic or shirt has a high collar and at least three top buttons. In the lower two corners of the image, pictured outside the laurel wreath, are two figures on horseback. These are the Merchant on the left and the Wife of Bath on the right, both from Chaucer's Canterbury Tales. The Merchant faces right. He appears to wear a hat or helmet. His right leg extends forward to rest in a stirrup, and his right hand grasps a bridle. The horse faces right and is likely trotting or walking. Also on horseback, the Wife of Bath rides side-saddle and faces forward and left. She wears a hat and a veil or drapery, perhaps a wimple, that covers her shoulder and neck. The rider's horse faces left with its front left leg raised off the ground.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the bust of a male figure, Geoffrey Chaucer, is depicted. Situated inside the wreath, Chaucer faces left and looks downward, perhaps toward the small figure to his left. His mouth is closed but he may be smiling. He has a bare forehead, with some hair visible above his right ear, thin eyebrows, and well-defined eye lashes. His tunic or shirt has a high collar and at least three top buttons. His head is mostly covered by a turban-like cloth or drapery which folds across his forehead and hangs to the right side of his face, draping behind his neck and back. His beard is short, and encircles his mouth and covers his chin.

In the center of the composition, the bust of a male figure, Geoffrey Chaucer, is encircled by a vegetative wreath of intertwined stems and flame-like leaves. It is probably a fruiting laurel wreath. The circular shape of this wreath appears to be formed by two separate branches or stems of laurel which overlap in the lower margin of the image. These two branches curve outwards and up, encircling Chaucer's bust. Flame-like leaves grow from each branch. Buds or fruits appear along each branch. As they curve inward, the laurel branches bifurcate so that the stems intertwine as they reach the top margin of the image.
Two indistinct, decorate objects, which may be palm fronds or feathers, extend from the middle of the left and right margins to the top corners.

Two figures riding horses are depicted outside of the laurel wreath, one in each lower corner of the image. The figure on the left is the Merchant from Chaucer's Canterbury Tales . He faces right. He appears to wear a hat or helmet and may have a beard. His visible right eye looks forward and may look up. Around his neck, there may be cloth or drapery that extends from his headpiece, or it may be a scarf, ruff, or armor. His upper body appears to be encased in a breastplate or dressed in a tunic or shirt. He sits or straddles the horse, and his right leg extends forward to rest in a stirrup. His right arm bends at the elbow to hold the reins with a clenched fist.

The figure in the left corner of the image rides a horse as it walks or trots forward, facing right with its head facing down. Its left front leg is raised and bent with its left hoof above the ground. Its right front leg is extended with its hoof planted on the ground. The horse's right back leg is bent, with its right hoof above the ground. Its left back leg is extended and its hoof appears to be touching the ground. There is a blanket under the horse's saddle.

Two figures riding horses are depicted outside of the laurel wreath, one in each lower corner of the image. The Figure on the right is the Wife of Bath from Chaucer's Canterbury Tales . She faces forward and to the left. She wears a pointed hat or helmet and, beneath it, drapery or a veil which may be a wimple that covers her neck and shoulders. She wears a robe and rides side-saddle, and bends her left arm to hold the reins with at least one hand. Her right leg appears to be bent at the knee, so that her legs are spread slightly as she sits.

The figure in the right corner of the image rides a horse as it walks or trots forward, facing left with its head down. The horse's left side is visible. The horse faces left with its head down, showing a curling mane. Its right front leg is raised and bent with its left hoof above the ground. Its left front leg is extended with its hoof on the ground. The horse's right back leg is bent, with its right hoof on the ground. Its left back leg is extended and its hoof appears to be touching the ground. It appears to be saddled and bridled.

objnote.p: The portrait of the Portuguese poet Luis Vaz de Camões (or Camoens, 1524?-80) is based on the frontispiece engraving in Camoens’ epic, *The Lusiads*, translated by Richard Fanshaw (1655), a copy of which was in Hayley’s library. The ship and anchor left of the portrait allude to Vasco de Gama’s voyage to India, one of the subjects of *The Lusiads*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, Luis Vaz de Camões(or Camoens, 1524?-80), is encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves of what may be palm, and a vine with smaller leaves which wraps around the broader palm leaves which make up the majority of the wreath. This vine may be an ivy of some kind, but is not obviously distinguishable as any specific type of vegetation. Situated inside the wreath, Camoens is depicted in the foreground facing right. He is pictured with short, curly hair, a mustache, and beard. His left ear is visible, and his left eye is pictured as open and looking out towards the viewer. His right eye is closed, probably to depict Camoens was blind in his right eye. He is pictured wearing a large ruff around his neck and also clearly wears some other clothing, possibly a robe or tunic. Blue coloring in the top margin of the design may indicate sky. In the lower left corner of the design are two nautical objects. In the foreground, a large hooked anchor wrapped in a chain or rope is visible. In the background may be the bow of a wooden ship. Colorful blotches of green and yellow may indicate some indeterminate vegetation, or may indicate waves, foam, or sea spray. In the lower right corner of the design, a sharp, pointed object appears to extend from behind the vegetation of the central wreath. This may be a harpoon or some other kind of hook or weapon. Blue washes in the right margin of the design may indicate water or sky.

He is pictured wearing a large ruff around his neck and also clearly wears some other clothing, possibly a robe or tunic.

objnote.p: The portrait of Alonso de Ercilla y Zúñiga (1533-94) is based on the engraved bust of the Spanish poet by Manuel Salvador Carmona published in the second volume of Juan José López de Sedano’s *Parnaso español* (1770). Hayley owned a copy of seven of the nine volumes of the 1768-78 edition of Sedano’s book. Hayley’s references to it in his *Essay on Epic Poetry* (1782) indicate that the Sedano volumes were very probably in his library by 1800. The arrows (left) and feathered bonnet (right) allude to Ercilla’s epic poem about the wars between the Spaniards and Indians in Chile.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The entirety of this design is composed of the head and neck of a male figure, Alonso de Ercilla y Zúñiga (1533-94), who is depicted in profile facing right, and encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. The wreath is composed of two obviously different sets of foliage. One variety of foliage appears with long, thin leaves--these may be palm fronds, grass stems, or another indeterminate vegetation. Another variety, mixed less abundantly into the longer leaves, are smaller, broader leaves with clear stems visible, possibly bay leaves. This wreath likely originates in the center of the design's lower margin where the two sides of the wreath's vegetative bunches overlap. These overlapping bundles of vegetation appear to be bound by intertwining ribbons, rope, or strips of cloth which drape through to the right side of the design. The wreath forms a circular shape surrounding Ercilla's head and neck entirely. Situated inside the wreath, Ercilla is pictured in profile in great detail, with short, curling hair and he is facing right. Ercilla's right ear is visible, and his face is bearded. Ercilla is depicted wearing a metallic collar and ruff, possibly parts of military attire. Folds of fabric or another ruffle of some kind is visible below the metallic collar and may be another piece of clothing: a robe, tunic, cloak, or another type of military dress. A band or circlet with feathers attached by their shafts may be a feathered headdress or crown pictured in the lower right corner of the design, in the foreground, in front of the wreath. Peeking out from behind the wreath in the lower left corner of the design are an arrowhead and the fletching, the feathered end, of another arrow. In the upper right margin, the long stalks of grass or another indeterminate vegetation is depicted growing vertically outside the central wreath, with the tips of these stalks bending in towards the central wreath. Some waving lines in the upper left margin of the design may also be vegetation--stalks of grass or flame-like leaves of some kind.

Folds of fabric or another ruffle of some kind is visible below the metallic collar and may be another piece of clothing: a robe, tunic, cloak, or another type of military dress.

The entirety of this design is composed of the head and neck of a male figure, Alonso de Ercilla y Zúñiga, who is depicted in profile facing right, and encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. The wreath is composed of two obviously different sets of foliage. One variety of foliage appears with long, thin leaves--these may be palm fronds, grass stems, or another indeterminate vegetation. Another variety, mixed less abundantly into the longer leaves, are smaller, broader leaves with clear stems visible, possibly bay leaves. This wreath originates in the center of the design's lower margin where the two sides of the wreath's vegetative, bundled branches overlap. The wreath forms a circular shape surrounding Ercilla's head and neck entirely.

This wreath likely originates in the center of the design's lower margin where the two sides of the wreath's vegetative bunches overlap. These overlapping bundles of vegetation appear to be bound by intertwining ribbons, rope, or strips of cloth which drape or trail off to the right side of the design.
A band or circlet with feathers attached by their shafts may be a feathered headdress or crown pictured in the lower right corner of the design, in the foreground, in front of the wreath.
Peeking out from behind the wreath in the lower left corner of the design are an arrowhead and the fletching, the feathered end, of another arrow.

In the upper right margin, the long stalks of grass or another indeterminate vegetation is depicted extending vertically towards the top of the design and outside the central wreath, with the tips of these stalks bending in towards the central wreath. Some waving, curved lines in the upper left margin of the design may also be vegetation--stalks of grass or flame-like leaves of some kind.

objnote.p: The portrait of the Italian poet Torquato Tasso (1544-95) is based on the engraving by N. Depuis after Enoch Seeman published as the frontispiece in Jacob Tonson's two volume edition of Tasso's *Gierusalemme Liberata* (1724). A copy of this work was in Hayley's Library. The angels right and left and the back view of a woman on the left probably allude to the liberation of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre that concludes Tasso's chief work, *Gierusalemme liberata*. Hayley's library included two translations of the epic. A lost drawing of the Sepulchre by William Hayley's son, Thomas Alphonso Hayley, might be the source for Blake's design. The drawing is known only through references to it in Thomas Hayley's letter of 11 January 1796 to William Hayley and letters by William Hayley of 11 and 14 January 1796 to his son Thomas.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, Torquato Tasso (1544-95), is encircled by a vegetative wreath of long, thin, overlapping leaves or stems of grass. The wreath is likely composed of grass, palm fronds, or another indeterminate, flame-like vegetation. This wreath seems to be one, continuous circle without an origin point--unlike other heads of poets designs, this wreath does not have obviously overlapping branches or stems. Situated inside the wreath, Tasso is pictured as balding with some short, curly hair and is facing and looking left. Tasso's left ear is visible. His face is bearded, and he is wearing a cloth collar. Two figures are pictured to the left of the wreath. One kneeling, winged, robed female figure is pictured in profile with shoulder-length hair and faces right with her right arm and hand outstretched. She is pictured as bending forward and to the right and may be praying, supplicating, or communicating with the other figures in this scene. She may be an angel, a saint, or another Christian holy figure. Facing away from the viewer, seen from behind, another kneeling female figure is pictured with her arms lifted and bent at the elbows, and, although her hands are obscured by her head, they are likely positioned on her head or covering her face in some way. This figure is pictured wearing a long cloth veil or a shroud and long gown or robe with a train or long skirt. She faces the arched opening of what is likely a tomb or building and kneels on what appears to be a stone step at its entrance. This scene likely represents the Virgin visiting the tomb. Above and in the background of the opening of the structure, the pointed tops of several tall shrubs or trees, or another flame-like vegetation, are visible. In the top left margin of the design, and in the corner of the lower left of the design, several sweeping green masses seem to indicate indeterminate vegetation of some kind, possibly moss or grass. To the right of the central wreath, the tomb's arched opening continues, as does the step or platform which appears to the left of the wreath. Another winged figure, also pictured in profile and facing left, kneels to the right of the wreath, with left arm and hand outstretched and right arm resting on the figure's right thigh. This figure leans forward slightly, and appears to have long hair and may be robed. It is not clear whether this figure is male or female. Above the cavern opening to the right of the wreath, the pointed tops of several tall shrubs or trees, or another flame-like vegetation, are visible. In the top corners of the design, several arching branches, possibly of willow trees, arch inwards towards the center of the design. Some dark, indeterminate vegetation (perhaps moss) obscures the step in the bottom right corner of the design. In the lower left margin of the design, a dark wash may indicate lapping water creeping up the steps of the structure, or may be vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, Torquato Tasso, is encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. Tasso is pictured as balding with some short, curly hair and is facing and looking left. His left ear is visible. His face is bearded, and he is wearing a cloth collar.

In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, Torquato Tasso, is encircled by a vegetative wreath of long, thin, overlapping leaves or stems of grass. The wreath is likely composed of grass, palm fronds, or another indeterminate, flame-like vegetation. This wreath seems to be one, continuous circle without an origin point--unlike other heads of poets designs, this wreath does not originate in the lower margin and is not obviously constructed from at least two layered branches or stems .

Two figures are pictured to the left of the wreath. One kneeling, winged, robed female figure is pictured in profile with shoulder-length hair and faces right with her right arm and hand outstretched. She is pictured as bending forward and to the right and may be praying, supplicating, or communicating with the other figures in this scene. She may be an angel, a saint, or another Christian holy figure.

Facing away from the viewer, seen from behind, another kneeling female figure is pictured with her arms lifted and bent at the elbows, and, although her hands are obscured by her head, they are likely positioned on her head or covering her face in some way. This figure is pictured wearing a long cloth veil or a shroud and long gown or robe with a train or long skirt. She faces the arched opening of what may be a tomb or building, and kneels on what appears to be a stone step at its entrance. This figure may be the holy virgin.

A female figure faces the arched opening of what may be a tomb or building, and kneels on what appears to be a stone step at its entrance. This opening extends on both sides of the image's central head in the wreath, which appears to be superimposed center of this structure. The step or plinth is also visible on both sides of the image's central wreath.
Above and in the background of the opening of the structure, the pointed tops of several tall shrubs or trees, or another flame-like vegetation, are visible.

Another winged figure, also pictured in profile and facing left, kneels to the right of the wreath, with left arm and hand outstretched and right arm resting on the figure's right thigh. This figure bends forward and to the left slightly, and appears to have long hair and may be robed. It is not clear whether this figure is male or female.
In the top corners of the design, several arching branches, possibly of willow trees, arch inwards towards the center of the design.
Some dark, indeterminate vegetation (perhaps moss) obscures the step in the bottom right corner of the design.
In the lower left margin of the design, a dark wash may indicate lapping water creeping up the steps of the structure, or may be a shadow or vegetation.

objnote.p: The portrait of the English poet Edmund Spenser (c. 1552-99) is probably based on George Vertue’s engraving of 1727 among his series of “Twelve Celebrated English Poets.” The medal hanging from Spenser’s collar, inscribed “ELIZA[BETH],” does not appear in the print and is presumably Blake’s addition. The designs left and right of the portrait are probably allusions to Spenser’s poem, *The Shepherd’s Calendar*, particularly the April eclogue. The aged figure holding a staff on the right may be Hobbinol from the poem; the crowned woman sitting far left may be Queen Elizabeth, described in the eclogue as “a mayden Queene” wearing a “cremosin coronet.”

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, Edmund Spenser (c. 1552-99), is encircled by a vegetative wreath. The wreath is likely composed of two individual branches of olives and olive leaves. This wreath originates in the center of the design's lower margin. Situated inside the wreath, Spenser is pictured with short, curly hair, a mustache, and a beard. Spenser is facing left. His right earlobe is visible. Spenser is wearing an intricate collar with a lace border. The patterned cloth just beneath this collar could indicate a coat. Also visible under the figure's collar is a large disc with the image of a woman wearing a ruff, a bodice, and a skirt. The disc may be a pendant or medal of some kind, and the woman represented on it may be Queen Elizabeth I. Encircling the central figure and wreath are a group of figures, nymphs, with clasped hands who appear to fly or float in misty clouds or wind. Stars and a dark wash indicate these figures are positioned in the night sky. Three figures are pictured with clasped hands on the left side of the design. In the top left margin of the design, a figure, who is probably female, faces right, and is depicted flying or floating with her right arm outstretched. Her right hand grasps the hand of the figure pictured right and below her. She appears to be gowned, and has long hair. This figure's body is depicted in shadow so that many details about her person are obscured. Another female figure flies or floats below and to the right. She faces out and towards the viewer. Both her arms are outstretched, with her left arm reaching out and back to the figure behind her and her right arm reaching down towards the figure below. Her left hand grasps the hand of figure behind. Her right hand touches the wrist of the figure below. This middle figure has curly, long hair. She appears to be loosely draped in cloth or fabric, and section of which appears to be blown by the wind or the movement of the figures so that it covers her breasts and trails upwards. The clouds, mist, or wind in which the figures fly obscures the details of this figure's body and legs. A third female figure is pictured below this middle figure. She faces right. Her left arm is outstretched and reaches down. Her right arm reaches back so that her right hand touches the right wrist of the middle figure. The third figure has long curly hair and wears a band of cloth or a circlet of some kind in her hair, which is blown back by the wind or the movement of the figures. She appears to be gowned or wrapped in cloth or fabric which covers her body and blows back and up towards the middle figure. These figures form a semi-circle which curves around the left side of the design's central wreath. They appear to fly or float in sweeping clouds which form flame-like shapes in the lower margin of the design. One star is visible in the left margin of the design. Another celestial body, a crescent moon, is pictured in the lower left corner of the design. Crouching in the curve of this crescent moon, and pictured leaning back against the moon, is a female figure wearing a long gown. This figure looks right, her hair is short and curly, styled similarly to Queen Elizabeth I's. The similarity is further emphasized by the figure's clothing; she wears a large, lacy ruff collar and a crown. This figure's left arm is bent at the elbow with her forearm pointing upwards, her hand mostly closed, and index finger pointing upwards, perhaps gesturing towards something, or providing a warning. The figure's right arm is bent at the elbow, and the details of her right hand are somewhat difficult to make out. However, her right hand may be spread open on her lap. Both her legs are covered by her long gown, but they are clearly bent at the knees with her lower legs tucked underneath her. She may be resting on the heels of her feet as she crouches on the moon. Encircling the wreath in the right margin are another pair of flying or floating figures in wispy clouds or wind. The uppermost figure appears to be female, whose curly hair appears to be pulled back into a bun. She faces down, but her upper body is twisted out and to the right. Her left arm reaches up with her hand outstretched. Her right arm reaches down and her right hand reaches towards the figure below her, though it is not clear that their hands touch. This upper figure wears a gown or is draped in cloth which floats around her and obscures her lower body. A lower figure to the right of the central wreath is seen from behind. She reaches up towards the figure above her with her right arm and her right hand outstretched. Her left arm stretches to the left, with her left hand gracefully posed. Her face appears to look up towards the figure above her. Her long curly hair drifts out to the left and may be arranged in a braid. She may be nude, and draped in cloth or fabric which covers her right shoulder and drapes around her lower body and legs, which are positioned to the figure's left. Four stars are visible in the right margin of the design, one of which appears as part of the central wreath, and three appear in the dark wash suggesting a night sky in the upper right margin of the design. A robed male figure appears to the far right of the central wreath and flying figures. He stands facing left and down. He has long hair and a beard. His face is depicted in profile so that his left eye, which is shown as a distinctive dark black mark, is visible to the viewer. His right arm is bent at the elbow, and his right forearm and hand appear to rest on his chest. His left arm is extended down at his left side and his left hand holds a long staff which may mark him as a shepherd. The figure's long robes obscure his legs and feet. This figure may be a representation of Spenser himself as a shepherd-poet serving Queen Elizabeth, or he may be Hobbinol, a character in Spenser's The Shepherd's Calendar, from which the other figures in this design are likely derived.

objnote.p: The portrait of the English poet and playwright William Shakespeare (1564-1616) is based on the famous engraving by Martin Droeshout, first published as the frontispiece in *Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies*, 1623. Both of the side designs, possibly based on a lost drawing by William Hayley’s son, Thomas Alfonso Hayley, illustrate act 4, scene 1, in *Macbeth*, with the three witches and Macbeth on the right and Banquo’s ghost on the left, pointing to the first in the line of kings. The lost drawing is known only through references to it in William Hayley’s *Memoirs*, not published until 1823, and John Flaxman’s letter to William Hayley of 5 July 1799. Blake’s pencil sketch of c. 1785, *Macbeth and the Ghost of Banquo*, is a different composition based on a different scene in the play.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, William Shakespeare (1564-1616), is encircled by a leafy vine which forms a wreath shape as it grows on a structure that arches over the figure's head. This wreath-like shape appears to be composed of country plants, possibly including a morning glory vine with leaves and at least three morning glory blossoms pictured to the left of the figure. Another variety of flowering plant may be intertwined with the vine in the lower margin of the design as some small flowers or buds appear to be growing among the morning glory leaves and blossoms. However, this vegetation is indeterminate. Situated inside the wreath, Shakespeare is pictured as balding, with hair growing around the crown of his head and at his temples. His portrait is based on the famous engraving by Martin Droeshout. Shakespeare's face is depicted in detail, with both eyes and eyebrows visible. He is pictured with a short mustache and a tuft of hair that grows just below his lower lip. Shakespeare wears a large, broad collar which mostly obscures the other clothing he wears--though it may be the collar of a coat. Two figures are pictured to the left of the central figure of Shakespeare. One figure, probably Banquo's ghost from Shakespeare's play, Macbeth is male and stands looking back over his left shoulder with both arms reaching left and hands outstretched, towards the second figure. Banquo may be gesturing or pointing toward this figure, or reaching towards it. Banquo wears a full suit of armor and a helmet. He appears to be walking towards the second figure, striding with his left leg extended back and his weight distributed between his right leg and the ball of his left foot. The second figure appears situated behind Banquo's outstretched arms. This figure may be the first in the line of kings conjured up by Banquo. It is depicted as faceless with a what appears to be a long hooded cloak or robe enshrouding him, and obscuring his body entirely. A series of triangular points on top of this figure's head is likely a crown. A tree appears to grow in the far left margin of the design, with branches and needle-like leaves arching towards the design's central figure. Pictured to the right of the central wreath are four figures. In the foreground, a male figure in full armor and wearing a helmet (likely Macbeth) stands with his legs wide apart and his upper body leaning to the right. The figure's mouth appears to be open in terror, and his arms seem to ward off the other three figures he is pictured with. His left arm is raised and bent at the elbow, with his left forearm raised in front of his face, his hand and fingers spread, and left palm facing away from his face. Macbeth's right arm is also raised, but is pictured lower. His right palm is facing towards the other figures in the scene as though to ward them off or protect himself. Behind Macbeth, and pictured as seated crouching, or kneeling in a group are three female figures who are likely witches. They each wear a cloth head covering, possibly wimples, and appear to be gowned. They each look up and to the right, towards Macbeth. The female figure pictured to the far right has both hands on her face, and her forearms are visible with her elbows propped on her gowned knees. The female figure at the far left of this group is pictured in profile and appears to be frowning. She seems to be kneeling, and her arms may be crossed in front of her, or she may be holding something that obscures her arms, or her arms may be hidden under her clothing. The female figure in the middle of the group is almost entirely obscured by the other two figures. Just her face and covered head are visible. At the feet of this four-person group are the flames of a fire, suggesting that the three witches sit by a bonfire when Macbeth encounters them. In the top right margin of the design, several arching diagonal lines suggest vegetation, likely palm fronds and other indeterminate vegetation.

Shakespeare wears a large, broad collar which mostly obscures the other clothing he wears--though it may be the collar of a coat.

Behind Macbeth, and pictured as seated, crouching, or kneeling in a group are three female figures who are likely witches. objnote.p: Milton. The portrait of the English poet John Milton (1608-74) is probably based on the engraving by Giovanni Battista Cipriani of a bust of Milton, derived from William Faithorne’s engraving of Milton and published in *Memoirs of Thomas Hollis* (1780). Cipriani pictures Milton with irises turned upward and barely represented, as though clouded with the blindness that afflicted the poet in his later years. Blake follows Cipriani’s rendering of Milton’s eyes, whereas Faithorne’s engraving presents a sighted Milton. Blake probably became familiar with the Hollis volume because Blake’s engraving master, James Basire, engraved ten of its thirty-seven plates, some probably executed during Blake’s term of apprenticeship. Henry Crabb Robinson, in his conversations with Blake, and Samuel Palmer in a letter of 1879 to George Richmond, noted Blake’s interest in the portraits of Milton in Hollis’s *Memoirs* (see Bentley, *Records*, pages 428-29). The snake, both right and left of the central portrait, and the fruit in his mouth refer to Satan in his serpent form and the fall of Eve in Milton’s *Paradise Lost*. The harp (left) and musical pipes (right) allude to Milton as a writer of both epics and pastoral poems.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, John Milton (1608-74), is encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. The wreath is composed of intertwining branches of several types of vegetation and fruit, including bay leaves, bay berries, oak leaves, acorns, and one large fruit attached to a leafy, twining stem which may be an apple. This wreath originates in the center of the design's lower margin where the wreath's two sections seem to overlap and may be connected by what looks like a wide ribbon or swath of cloth. Situated inside the wreath, Milton is pictured with long, shoulder-length curling hair and is facing left. Milton's face is depicted in the style of Greek statuary so that his eyes appear under their lids as smooth spheres, possibly depicting the blindness which afflicted Milton in his later years. Milton is pictured wearing a wide, folded collar with a patterned neck cloth or kerchief partially visible and protruding from under this large collar. Above the wreath, several arching branches of vegetation, probably palm fronds, extend towards the central wreath. Below the wreath, a large, scaly serpent winds its way around the lower margin of the design. The serpent's head and upper half of its scaly body are visible to the left of the wreath. The serpent's head and upper body twists over itself so that it forms a single loop and its head faces right with mouth open. Small teeth are visible. A round object, probably a fruit like an apple, is pictured in the serpent's mouth. Its right eye is visible, and the scales on the serpent's head form flame-like spikes at the base of the head. The lower half of the serpent's scaly body and long tail are pictured to the right of the wreath, with the tail twisting over itself and forming a loop so that the tip of the serpent's tail points in towards the center of the design. In the left margin of the design is a harp decorated with what may be an angel. To the right of the wreath in the right margin of the design, the trunk of a palm tree is visible. Three pipe-like objects are also visible in the right margin of the design. These may be the pipes of an instrument like organ pipes or the pipes of a large bagpipe.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, John Milton, is encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. Milton is pictured with long, shoulder-length curling hair and is facing left. His face is depicted in the style of Greek statuary so that his eyes appear under their lids as smooth spheres, possibly depicting the blindness which afflicted him in his later years. Milton is pictured wearing a wide, folded collar with a patterned neck cloth or kerchief partially visible and protruding from under this large collar.

In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, John Milton, is encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. The wreath is composed of intertwining branches of several types of vegetation and fruit, including bay leaves, bay berries, oak leaves, acorns, and one large fruit attached to a leafy, twining stem which may be an apple. This wreath originates in the center of the design's lower margin where the wreath's two sections seem to overlap and may be connected by what looks like a wide ribbon or cloth.
Above the wreath, several arching branches of vegetation, probably palm fronds, extend towards the central wreath.

Below the wreath, a large, scaly serpent winds its way around the lower margin of the design. The serpent's head and upper half of its scaly body are visible to the left of the wreath. The serpent's head and upper body twists over itself so that it forms a single loop and its head faces right with mouth open. Small teeth are visible. A round object, probably a fruit like an apple, is pictured in the serpent's mouth. Its right eye is visible, and the scales on the serpent's head form flame-like spikes at the base of the head. The lower half of the serpent's scaly body and long tail are pictured to the right of the wreath, with the tail twisting over itself and forming a loop so that the tip of the serpent's tail points in towards the center of the design.
A round object, probably a fruit like an apple, is pictured in the serpent's mouth.
In the left margin of the design is a harp decorated with what may be a winged angel.
To the right of the wreath in the right margin of the design, the trunk of a palm tree is visible.
Three pipe-like objects are also visible in the right margin of the design. These may be the pipes of an instrument like organ pipes or the pipes of a large bagpipe.

objnote.p: The portrait of the English poet John Dryden (1631-1700) is based on George Vertue’s engraving after Godfrey Kneller’s painting first published in Dryden’s *Dramatic Works* (1717). Hayley owned a copy of the 1735 edition, also containing the engraving. The scene on the left illustrates the opening lines of Dryden’s poem, *Alexander’s Feast or the Power of Music*. The man is Alexander; the woman is the courtesan Thais.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Located centrally in this design are the head and neck of a male figure, John Dryden (1631-1700), encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. The leaves of this wreath are not highly distinctive, however the wreath is likely composed of bay or laurel leaves and stems. This wreath likely originates in the center of the design's lower margin where the stems of two sage branches are visibly overlapping. The wreath forms a circular shape surrounding John Dryden's head, neck, and right shoulder entirely. Situated inside the wreath, John Dryden is pictured in great detail, with short, wavy hair. He faces right, but his face is turned so that he looks over his right shoulder with his eyes pointing to the left. Both his eyes are visible, as is his right earlobe. Under Dryden's chin and jaw, the folds of a cloth shirt collar and the fabric of a shirt are visible. His clothed right shoulder is visible. To the left of the central wreath, a scene with two figures is lightly rendered, and illustrates the opening lines of Dryden's poem, Alexander's Feast or the Power of Music. In the foreground, a nude male figure, Alexander, is seated on what may be a bench or the seat of a litter or chariot. His upper body faces out towards the viewer, but his legs are situated so that they face right. This figure's face is pictured in profile, and he looks back to his left towards the figure seated next to him. He has short hair, and a vegetative crown of leaves and fruit (possibly figs and fig leaves) resting on his head. The figure's nude torso faces out towards the viewer. His right arm is bent at the elbow, and right hand rests on the arm of the bench on which he sits. His right leg is bent at the knee and his lower leg is extended with his bare foot visible. His left leg is bent at the knee with his lower leg bent under the bench and resting on the balls of his left foot. A piece of cloth or fabric drapery is arranged over the figure's lap and covers his upper thighs and drapes over his right hip. The figure may be gently holding this fabric with the tips of his fingers on his right hand. Sitting next to, and partially obscured by, the male figure is a female figure, Thais, who is also seated. She is loosely draped in a gown, fabric, or drapery of some kind which reveals her right shoulder and breast. Like her companion, her upper body faces outwards to the viewer. Her face is also turned outwards, and her eyes look up and to the right. She may also have a headdress of some kind on, though the details are quite faint. Her left arm is bent at the elbow, which rests on her left knee. She rests her head in her left hand. Her bent legs are covered by her long gown. At her feet, a round object is pictured, though it is not clear what this object is. The feet of the male figure rest on a step or plinth, or the raised platform of a litter or chariot. The right side of this structure is visible, and forms the arm of the bench on which the two figures sit. This right side appears to be adorned by two crossed thin rectangular shapes which form an "x." These may be straps or bands designed to help transport or carry the litter. Above the bench are swooping shapes which may represent curtains or a canopy made of cloth. In the top left margin of the design, the branches and needle-like leaves of what may be palm trees appear. In the lower left corner of the design, several small shadows may represent the folds of curtains, or may be some indeterminate vegetation. The space to the right of the central wreath is largely vacant of any design. The exception is that the knees, calves, and right foot of a human figure are very faintly visible in the lower right margin. The scale of these limbs indicate that the figure to whom they belong was likely quite large. However, any other details of this figure are not visible.

objnote.p: The portrait of the English dramatist Thomas Otway (1652-85) is derived from Jacobus Houbraken’s engraving of Mary Beale’s painting first published in Thomas Birch’s *Heads of Illustrious Persons of Great Britain* (1741). A re-engraving of this portrait by John Miller appears in the 1757 edition of Otway’s Works owned by Hayley. The scene on the right pictures Jaffier threatening to kill his wife, Belvidera, in Otway’s play, *Venice Preserved*. Venice is pictured on the left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Located centrally in this design are the head and neck of a male figure, English dramatist Thomas Otway (1652-1685), encircled by a vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves. The leaves of this wreath are not highly distinctive, however the wreath is likely composed of sedge and grasses. This wreath likely originates in the center of the design's lower margin where two branches are visibly overlapping. The wreath forms a circular shape surrounding John Otway's head and neck. Situated inside the wreath, Thomas Otway is pictured in great detail, with shoulder-length, wavy hair. He faces forward, and rests his right cheek on the backs of his fingers of his closed right hand. His right pinky is the only finger that is visible, the others appear to be closed in his hand. His right wrist is visible, as is the cuff of his right shirt sleeve. Both his eyes are visible, as is his right earlobe. Under Otway's chin and jaw, the folds of a cloth collar and the fabric of a shirt are visible. To the left of the central wreath, a city surrounded by water is visible, pictured under a night sky. This is Venice, the location of Otway's play, Venice Preserved. Green wash in the lower left margin appears to be the bank beside a body of water. Just beyond it, a section of blue represents a short stretch of water, with at least one boat floating down it. A mark just above the boat could be a figure rowing or steering the boat. A stone bridge arches from the bank across the water to the walls of the city beyond. At least six conical or pointed spires are visible beyond the city walls. The roofs of several buildings indicate several structures within the walls. One dome may represent a cathedral or another large structure. In the wash of blue above the city, a sickle moon indicates a night sky. In the far left margin of the design, in the foreground of this landscape, there is a brushy shrub or another indeterminate vegetation. In the upper left corner and in the upper left margin of the design, arching leaves grow upward and curve in towards the design's central wreath. These appear to be palm fronds. Two figures are pictured in the lower right margin of the design. A male figure stands with his legs bent at the knee and braced. He appears to be wearing a shirt; a collar is pictured clearly at the base of his neck. However, his muscled legs do not appear to be clothed, perhaps he is wearing tights which cover his thighs. He appears to have short, curly hair, and he faces right and looks down at the second figure who kneels at his feet. His left leg is positioned forward so that he appears to be lunging forward with his right leg bearing his weight. His right arm is raised, and he appears to hold a dagger in his clenched right fist, in the act of stabbing the figure at his feet. His left arm reaches out and grasps the second figure, though it is not clear how he holds her--he may be clutching the figure's neck. A long, pointed object is pictured behind the figure's left leg and may be a scabbard or a sword. The second, female figure kneels in the foreground. She is pictured from behind, and faces right, looking up at the face of man who stands above her. Her hair is long and she wears a long dress or gown that obscures her legs, which appear to be bent at the knee as she kneels. Her left arm reaches up and is bent at the elbow to protect herself or plead with her assailant. She may be grasping the man's hand or forearm. Her head is bent back and she looks up towards the knife held over her. These figures are intended to represent Jaffier stabbing Belvidera in Otway's play, Venice Preserved. A dark mass in the far right margin could be another shrub or another indeterminate vegetation. Diagonal lines in the upper right margin could be palm fronds or some other indeterminate vegetation.
