objnote.p: The portrait of the English poet Alexander Pope (1688-1744) is based on one or more of the numerous engravings of the painting by Jean-Baptiste van Loo, probably known to Blake through the engraving by Jacobus Houbraken in Thomas Birch's *Heads of Illustrious Persons of Great Britain* (1741) or the plate signed "Cook" or "Sharp" and dated 1778 in John Bell's edition of *The Poets of Great Britain*. Hayley owned a copy of Bell's edition. The woman holding a sword and dagger on the left is based on the opening of Pope's "Elegy to the Memory of an Unfortunate Lady." The lady praying on the right is Eloisa from Pope's "Eloisa to Abelard." Both poems are printed in the 1797 edition of Pope's *Works*, a copy of which was in Hayley's library.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The composition depicts a bust of the poet Alexander Pope (1688-1744) surrounded by a wreath. The wreath seems to be made of several kinds of plant that overlap and intertwine. On the left side of the vine is multiple branches of what might be laurel, though it is possible that there are two kinds of foliage from trees present. On the right side of the wreath are at least two different types of vines. One might be ivy, and the central vine with thicker leaves might be a kind of fern, but it is indeterminate. At the center of the wreath is Pope, who is male. He has a prominent forehead and long, curly hair that might be a wig. His head is bent slightly back, resting against his hand with his fingers spread. His eyes are raised, facing right and up. He might be smiling. His clothing is only sketched, likely a coat and necktie, cravat, or piece of cloth around his neck with a shirt. On the right side of the composition is a female figure kneeling and praying. Her head is bent back, her eyes are raised and her hands are together with her arms bent upward. Her hair is covered by a long hood, and she is also wearing a gown. The figure might be inside a church or chapel based on the shape of the windows above her. There are three windows, all arched in the style of Gothic Art. The central window has a candle or lamp inside it. Because the walls of the room curve, the ceiling might be domed. This scene might be based on Pope's "Eloisa to Abelard," and the female figure is Eloisa. The left side of the composition is another female figure, dressed in a similar fashion of a hood that covers her head and a long gown. She is standing and facing forward with an expression of what might be melancholy. She is holding a sword and dagger, and is based on the opening of Pope’s “Elegy to the Memory of an Unfortunate Lady.” In the background there are three cypress trees, with one partially obscured by the wreath. In the sky is a crescent moon. The vegetation at the top corners of the painting are likely palm trees.

objnote.p: The portrait of the French writer François Marie Arouet de Voltaire (1694-1778) is based on the painting by Maurice Quentin de Latour of c. 1731, well known through several engravings such as those by Jean Baptiste Guélard (c. 1735) and Pierre Gabriel Langlois (1785). Joan of Arc on the left challenges the soldiers on the right, probably an allusion to Voltaire's unfinished satirical poem, *La Pucelle de Orléans* (begun 1730 but not published until 1762).

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the head and neck of a male figure, Francois-Marie Arouet de Voltaire (1694-1778), is encircled by a complicated, colorful vegetative wreath of overlapping leaves, fruit, and flowers. The wreath appears to be composed of a grape vine with curling tendrils, at least two separate bunches of grapes and grape leaves, and a variety of flowers with stems and leaves which may include honeysuckle, convolvulus, and pimpernel. Other vegetation is also pictured, but is indeterminate. These flora are arranged in a loose circular shape around Voltaire's head and neck, but unlike other heads of poets designs, the flora in this design is not a arranged in a tightly-constructed wreath. It is not bound by any tie or ribbon. Situated inside the wreath, Voltaire is pictured with long, shoulder-length, curly hair in the style of an intricate wig and is facing left. His face is depicted in detail, with both eyes and eyebrows visible. His nose is distinctively rendered as quite large and protruding. Voltaire is pictured wearing a cloth cravat which wraps around his neck and also includes a large ruffle which is mostly obscured by the wreath that encircles the figure. The collar of a coat or waistcoat is barely visible, and a mass of whirls on the figure's left shoulder may be a ruffle on his coat, or part of his curling hair. One female figure, Joan of Arc, is pictured to the left of the wreath in the left margin of the design, though some of the details of this figure are very lightly rendered making some of her features barely visible. This figure stands looking right with her left arm raised vertically and her left hand grasping a sword. Her right arm hangs by her side and is strapped into what appears to be a shield. The figure wears a plumed helmet and what appears to be a closely fitting bodice or a breastplate of armor. She is pictured with long hair and wears a long gown. Her right foot is visible, and appears to be covered in a slipper or insubstantial shoe of some kind. Also in the lower left margin of the design is a mass of curved lines and one dark shadow with some colorful streaks overlaying this design. It is unclear what this may be, though it could be the flames of a fire. A group of three male figures are pictured to the right of the design's central wreath. Their rendering is light, so that some of their features are indistinct. These figures are dressed in armor, and each appears to be wearing a helmet with a plume or crest and each is carrying a shield, a sword, and a spear. Each soldier appears to march or stride forward towards the female figure on the left side of the design. Each of their bearded faces look left. The points of four spears are visible above this group, suggesting that the three soldiers visible are followed by more who are not pictured. Across the top margin of the design, several arching diagonal lines suggest vegetation, likely palm fronds or indeterminate vegetation.

objnote.p: The portrait of the German poet Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock (1724-1803) is modelled on a mezzotint by Johann Gerhard Huck after a painting by Anton Hickel. On 14 Oct. 1800, Hayley’s friend William Meyer sent him a copy of this print (see Butlin 343.16). Both flanking vignettes may be incomplete or damaged, the one on the left showing only thorny brambles. The angel (note the shadowy wings) on the right holds a quill in her right hand. The figure might have been prompted by a passage in Klopstock’s poem “Siona,” included in the 1798 edition of his works in six volumes in Hayley’s library.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the bust of a male figure, the German poet Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock (1724-1803). His portrait is encircled by a vegetative wreath of two different plants the blend together at two points in the center, lower and upper, of the wreath. The plant on the left of the wreath is pine, based on its densely packed pine needles that grow from thin branches. The plant that makes up the right of the wreath may be non-flowering reed or grass because of the flat, pointed edge of its leaf. Situated inside the wreath, Klopstock faces left and looks upward, possibly towards descending leaves or fronds the appear at the upper left edge of the painting. His mouth is closed. He has large eyes and thin eyebrows, his forehead is bare due to the hair on his head being pulled back or the style of his wig. There are curls on either side of his head that partially cover his ears. He appears to be wearing a cravat around his neck, a waistcoat, and an outer coat. Both flanking vignettes may be incomplete or damaged. On the right side of the wreath is another figure, who due to the wings on her back appears to be an angel. She appears female, with her head is bent back as she faces left, eyes towards Klopstock. She has long, curly hair. She kneels beside the wreath and wears a long gown, while her arms are raised, with her right bent horizontally at the elbow, as though playing a harp. Her left is bent upward. Her visible hand is holding a quill. At the far lower left of the painting are long, white streaks that might be rib bones. The ground of the painting to the left of the wreath is covered in thorny brambles or vines.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the bust of a male figure, Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock, is encircled by a vegetative wreath of two different plants the blend together at two points in the center, lower and upper, of the wreath. Situated inside the wreath, Klopstock faces left and looks upward, possibly towards descending leaves or fronds the appear at the upper left edge of the painting. His mouth is closed. He has large eyes and thin eyebrows, his forehead is bare due to the hair on his head being pulled back or the style of his wig. There are curls on either side of his head that partially cover his ears. He appears to be wearing a cravat around his neck, a waistcoat, and an outer coat.

In the center of the composition, the bust of a male figure, Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock, is encircled by a vegetative wreath of two different plants the blend together at two points in the center, lower and upper, of the wreath. The plant on the left of the wreath is pine, based on its densely packed pine needles that grow from thin branches. The plant that makes up the right of the wreath may be non-flowering reed or grass because of the flat, pointed edge of its leaf.

On the right side of the wreath is another figure, who due to the feather-covered wings on her back appears to be an angel. She appears female, with her head is bent back as she faces left, eyes towards Klopstock. She has long, curly hair. She kneels beside the wreath and wears a long gown, while her arms are raised, with her right bent horizontally at the elbow. She holds a quill in her right hand. Her left arm is bent upward.
At the far lower left of the painting are long, white streaks that might be rib bones.
The ground of the painting to the left of the wreath is covered in thorny brambles or vines.

objnote.p: The portrait of Hayley’s friend, the English poet William Cowper (1731-1800), reproduces the pastel drawn by George Romney in 1792. In addition to this version among the Heads of Poets, Blake executed five other copies of Romney’s work: a pen and ink drawing and a pencil sketch, both datable to c. 1801 (Butlin 351-52), two water color miniatures datable to c. 1801 and c. 1801-04 (Butlin 353-54), and an engraving published in William Hayley’s *The Life, and Posthumous Writings, of William Cowper*, vol. 1 (1803). No textual sources have been found for the side vignettes. The dog (left) might be Beau, Cowper’s spaniel; the boy (right) might be Hayley’s son, Thomas Alphonso Hayley.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, the bust of a male figure, William Cowper (1731-1800), is encircled by a vegetative wreath of what appears to be a single type of plant. In contrast to thicker wreaths in the series, this one appears to be a single or two branches intertwined with thin leaves, likely olive based on the shape of the leaf and the fruit shown on the right side of the wreath. In the center of the wreath is Cowper, who is wearing a hat that is likely a night cap that covers his ears and hair. Cowper is wearing a high collar coat and a cravat tied into a bow around his neck. He is facing right, looking towards the other figure on the right of the wreath. The figure on the right of the composition is young and male, who appears to be running. His arms are raised vertically, and he holds an open book in his right hand. He has short, curly hair with his eyes raised. The boy is wearing an open collar shirt and breeches. He might be Hayley's son, Thomas Alphonso Hayley. On the left side of the wreath is a dog, who appears to be walking or pointing with its head while its leg is drawn up, like during a hunt. The dog might be Beau, Cowper's spaniel. Framing the composition are two trees on either side, with the one on the left fully visible. Based on the curve of their branches, these are likely willow trees.

objnote.p: The portrait of William Hayley’s son (1781-1800) is based on a drawing by Henry Howard copying a medallion by John Flaxman. Blake’s engraving of the medallion portrait was published in William Hayley’s *Essay on Sculpture* (1800). An untraced work by Blake, *Thomas Alphonso Hayley, Profile Drawing* (Butlin 344), datable to 1800, may have been a preliminary for the painting in the Heads of Poets series. The inclusion of “Tom” Hayley with eminent writers implies that the group of portraits was intended in part as a memorial to Hayley’s illegitimate son, dead at the age of nineteen.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The main part of the composition it the bust of a male figure, Thomas Alphonso Hayley (1781-1800), William Hayley's son. In the portrait he is young, facing forward with only one side of his face visible. He has short hair that partially covers his ear, and he is wearing an open collar shirt. The wreath around his bust is simple: based on the shape of the leaves, it looks to be made of ivy vines. The painting is old and the materials appear to be fading, but the bottom left and right of the wreath show two doves, their wings raised in flight, while their beaks are grabbing at parts of the wreath.
